messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Autonomous Planning Based on Spatial Concepts to Tidy Up Home Environments with Service Robots

Paper Abstract: Abstract Tidy-up tasks by service robots in home environments are challenging in robotics applications because they involve various interactions with the environment. In particular, robots are required not only to grasp, move, and release various home objects but also to plan the order and positions for placing the objects. In this paper, we propose a novel planning method that can efficiently estimate the order and positions of the objects to be tidied up by learning the parameters of a probabilistic generative model. The model allows a robot to learn the distributions of the co-occurrence probability of the objects and places to tidy up using the multimodal sensor information collected in a tidied environment. Additionally, we develop an autonomous robotic system to perform the tidy-up operation. We evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method by an experimental simulation that reproduces the conditions of the Tidy Up Here task of the World Robot Summit 2018 international robotics competition. The simulation results show that the proposed method enables the robot to successively tidy up several objects and achieves the best task score among the considered baseline tidy-up methods.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "What competitions were conducted in the service categories of the world robot summit?",
        "Learning to place new objects in a scene",
        "Interactively picking real-world objects with unconstrained spoken language instructions",
        "An everyday robotic system that maintains local rules using semantic map based on long-term episodic memory",
        "Tidy up my room : multi-agent cooperation for service tasks in smart environments",
        "Semantic mapping for mobile robotics tasks: A survey",
        "A review of spatial reasoning and interaction for real-world robotics",
        "Online spatial concept and lexical acquisition with simultaneous localization and mapping",
        "Simultaneous estimation of self-position and word from noisy utterances and sensory information",
        "Spatial concept acquisition for a mobile robot that integrates self-localization and unsupervised word discovery from spoken sentences",
        "Unsupervised spatial lexical acquisition by updating a language model with place clues",
        "Learning relationships between objects and places by multimodal spatial concept with bag of objects",
        "Semantic mapping based on spatial concepts for grounding words related to places in daily environments",
        "Which robot behavior can motivate children to tidy up their toys?: Design and evaluation of ranger",
        "Stationery holder robot that encourages office workers to tidy their desks",
        "Robot, organize my shelves! tidying up objects by predicting user preferences",
        "Simultaneous End-User Programming of Goals and Actions for Robotic Shelf Organization",
        "A Multimodal Classifier Generative Adversarial Network for Carry and Place Tasks From",
        "Automated task planning using object arrangement optimization",
        "Building 3d semantic maps for mobile robots using rgb-d camera",
        "Semanticfusion: Dense 3d semantic mapping with convolutional neural networks",
        "Meaningful maps with object-oriented semantic mapping",
        "Cnn-slam: Real-time dense monocular slam with learned depth prediction",
        "Multimodal sensor-based semantic 3d mapping for a large-scale environment",
        "Visual slam algorithms: a survey from 2010 to 2016",
        "System for augmented human-robot interaction through mixed reality and robot training by non-experts in customer service environments",
        "A constructive definition of Dirichlet priors",
        "Gibbs sampling methods for stick-breaking priors",
        "Machine learning: a probabilistic perspective",
        "A sticky HDP-HMM with application to speaker diarization",
        "Ros: an open-source robot operating system",
        "A flexible and scalable slam system with full 3d motion estimation",
        "Probabilistic robotics",
        "Yolov3: An incremental improvement",
        "Moveit!",
        "RoboCup@Home: Analysis and results of evolving competitions for domestic and service robots",
        "Development of human support robot as the research platform of a domestic mobile manipulator",
        "Design and use paradigms for gazebo, an open-source multi-robot simulator",
        "The Open Motion Planning Library",
        "Rrt-connect: An efficient approach to single-query path planning",
        "Rapidly-exploring random trees: A new tool for path planning",
        "Octomap: An efficient probabilistic 3d mapping framework based on octrees",
        "Online global loop closure detection for large-scale multi-session graph-based slam",
        "Human-Robot Collaborative High-Level Control with an Application to Rescue Robotics",
        "Imagenet classification with deep convolutional neural networks"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Autonomous Planning Based on Spatial Concepts to Tidy Up Home Environments with Service Robots, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
